posts.name: Carl Critchfield
posts.cooked:
One of our motor controllers was going into neutral (brake) at a very consistent period during forward driving, on the ground or on blocks. We tracked it down to one of our sub-systems causing a delay, and after removing it from the code the drive system was behaving normally again.

After this we noticed the can bus load was fluctuating from 35% to 70% in fractions of a second. This is definitely not normal, especially considering that by then we had removed practically everything except the drive code, so the can bus should be experience less than 35% load the entire time. We had just checked every connection in the drive system‚Äôs CAN bus, and reset all the CAN ids to troubleshoot the drive problems. We‚Äôre pretty stumped so any ideas at all would be greatly appreciated.

I‚Äôve attached a screenshot of the can bus load to show what I mean. 20220124_205635 4032√ó2268 701 KB

20220124_205635 4032√ó2268 701 KB

20220124_205635 4032√ó2268 701 KB

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
Since you say you already checked everything physical (wiring, etc), I would start looking for a software cause.  Comment out (or otherwise disable) as much as possible and confirm the symptom disappears, then re-add code until it reappears.  This is easy to do with command-based (if using java or c++, as the presence of the class is irrelevant so long as there‚Äôs no references to it), but can be done fairly easily regardless of the style of your code.

Also, please share your code if possible (ideally via github or similar source control platform) if you‚Äôd like more eyes on it.

posts.name: KJaget
posts.cooked:
Would also be useful to know which devices are on the CAN bus.

edit - that maybe sounded snarky, but not my intent. Posting code will help with some of it, but also good to know if the PH vs. PDP is used, same with a pneumatics controller and so on. Plus whatever devices might be on the bus but not yet programmed for, if any. Also, OG Rio or Rio2?  More details the better.

posts.name: NewtonCrosby
posts.cooked:
Which subsystem was the one you removed to make the driving symptoms go away?  What are the devices associated with that subsystem, etc?

While we‚Äôve never done it in production/competition code, one thing that I have experimented with in reducing the CAN bus traffic is to extend the manufacturer‚Äôs libraries.  We use talons, so briefly would be something like this:

May not fix your problem but your can bus utilization will certainly be a lot less.

Edited to add constructor in the off chance you just tried my code snippet directly

posts.name: Clayton Yocom
posts.cooked: This used to be necessary but I believe all of the modern FRC vendorlibs do this internally nowadays.

posts.name: NewtonCrosby
posts.cooked: I just did a cursory look at the WPI_TalonFX implementation, I didn‚Äôt see it in there.  Not sure about any of the other vendors.

posts.name: Jacob Caporuscio
posts.cooked:
The volatile fluctuation of the CAN bus utilization measurement was something we saw during beta - it appears to be a bug in the DS reporting of bus util.

There‚Äôs nothing that can be done on the user end to improve the measurement, but the good news is that this doesn‚Äôt impact the real bus utilization or your ability to use CAN devices.

NewtonCrosby:

May not fix your problem but your can bus utilization will certainly be a lot less.

Practically speaking on-change checking like this won‚Äôt impact your bus util. This is done in the low-level of Phoenix, plus the control data is sent periodically anyway.

posts.name: Carl Critchfield
posts.cooked:
Here‚Äôs our robot‚Äôs code that was causing the issue with the drive motor, I‚Äôve messaged Max, the software engineer who got it working again, to have him commit the working code, but from what he said I believe the only code left is the DriveSubsystem and the ManualDriveTank command, along with the bare-bones necessary stuff of course.

https://github.com/Carlthird/V386-Troubleshooting

posts.name: Carl Critchfield
posts.cooked: I see, is there anything in particular that seems to cause it? And could it present a hazard by pushing CAN bus utilization above 100% once we add more devices and code beyond those needed for just driving? Thanks!

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
Wanted to add here - for CTRE, checking this isn‚Äôt necessary.  However, if you are doing utilizing REV and setting PID constants it is absolutely necessary. Adding the ‚Äúon change‚Äù checking to REV for the spark max took us from over 80% to a much more reasonable 40%.

So in this case, be aware of what vendor you are using.

posts.name: Brian
posts.cooked:
You mention ‚ÄúAdding the ‚Äúon change‚Äù checking to the REV‚Äù‚Ä¶ Where is that? in code or in Rev Hardware?

Also, is a noisy can bus normal? our utilization is from 50% to 90%. The line graph is 40% wide. That is with the bot sitting.

Thanks!

posts.cooked:

Also, is a noisy can bus normal? our utilization is from 50% to 90%. The line graph is 40% wide.

posts.name: blueyoshi256
posts.cooked: We‚Äôre seeing a similar issue, only more extreme. It isn‚Äôt affecting our normal operation at all, but our CAN bus traffic is spiking roughly every 240 milliseconds, usually up to 100%. We think the culprit is the Falcon (TalonFX) motor controllers. The size of the traffic spike seemed to correlate with the number we had enabled. In addition, we looked at the get and set StatusFramePeriod functions (found in the CTRE BaseMotorController class). The getStatusFramePeriod suggested that the following statuses have a period of 240 milliseconds by default: Status 4: AinTempVbat (analog input, temperature, battery voltage) Status 12: Feedback1 Status 13: Base_PIDF0 Status 15: FirmwareApiStatus We then wrote some code to setStatusFramePeriod to various prime numbers, in the hopes of reducing the amount of overlap. However, when we ran this, it errored, making our TalonFXs to drop off the CAN bus. It‚Äôs quite possible we wrote some bad code, but we‚Äôre wondering if anybody else has attempted a similar solution, or if anybody has insight into why changing the status frame period could cause the TalonFXs to error Thanks!

posts.name: Colin Wong
posts.cooked: What was the error? And the spiking to 100% is normal due to the bug linked above.

posts.name: blueyoshi256
posts.cooked: I don‚Äôt recall the exact errors at the moment, but they seemed like the general ‚Äúcan‚Äôt find‚Äù error for the motors afterwards (all of the configuration commands afterwards failed, and it grayed out in Pheonix Tuner). Also, that bug sounds consistent with what we were seeing, but I‚Äôd be curious to know if it also explains the periodicity of the spikes.
